mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Studies of Magneto-Structural Correlations in Spin-Crossover Complexes

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Spin-crossover (SCO) is one of the most recognized spin-state switching phenomena as an example of molecular bistability. The ability to convert between high spin and low spin electronic configurations in a transition metal center under various external stimuli makes such compounds useful in the preparation of molecular memory devices, sensors, and switches. The phenomenon has been widely studied in six-coordinate first-row transition metal ions with electronic configurations 3d4-3d7 under an intermediate ligand field strength. This thesis explores the design of several new systems to induce SCO in Fe(II) complexes. The general SCO phenomenon and typical materials are overviewed in Chapter 1, and the general experimental methods used in this work are presented briefly in Chapter 2. Chapter 3 describes the design and characterization of Fe(II) homoleptic complexes containing ligands with mixed N,S- coordination. Such ligands are rarely used for the synthesis of SCO compounds, as compared to the widely studied SCO complexes with the N6 coordination environment. Mononuclear N4S2-coordinated SCO complexes with abrupt and hysteretic spin transitions and crystallographic symmetry-breaking were characterized by single crystal and synchrotron powder X-Ray diffraction, magnetic susceptibility measurements, MÃ¶ssbauer spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and optical spectroscopy to arrive at understanding of magneto-structural correlations and the interplay between the SCO behavior and symmetry-breaking. Chapters 4 and 5 describes the synthesis of new 2,2'-biimidazole type ligands that were N-alkylated at the protonated nitrogens with naphthalene, anthracene, and biphenyl-quinoxaline fragments and then used in the synthesis of Fe(II) SCO complexes. The difference in the structure-property relationship of the heteroleptic Fe(II) complexes has yielded distinct magnetic behaviors with different degrees of spin-transition abruptness and different temperatures at which the spin transition takes place. Lastly, Chapter 6 describes the design of Fe(II) complexes with non-innocent ligands. The initial results are encouraging, as we are able to switch the spin state of the Fe(II) center via reduction of non-innocent ligands in homoleptic complexes. Based on these initial findings, we offer synthetic recommendations that are derived from structural studies of extremely air- and moisture-sensitive homoleptic Fe(II) complexes with non-innocent ligands and Fe(II) complexes with non-innocent ligands combined with anions capable of electron-donation. Chapter 7 provides conclusions and general outlook at future research opportunities based on the results obtained in this thesis.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Mykhailo Shatruk, Professor Directing Dissertation; Stephen Hill, University Representative; Kenneth Hanson, Committee Member; Justin Kennemur, Committee Member.
